claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: In traditional quadrivalent standard dose inactivated influenza vaccines (SD-IIV4), chicken eggs are used to manufacture the vaccine strain.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote establishes that standard dose flu vaccines are produced using chicken eggs, which is relevant because egg-based production is known to allow for the possibility of mutations (antigenic drift) during manufacturing.

extracted_evidence.quote: The effectiveness of standard dose vaccines — especially against the influenza A H3N2 subtype — may be attenuated by antigenic drift during egg based manufacturing, whereas the recombinant vaccine is not susceptible to such drift.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote directly supports the claim by stating that egg-based manufacturing can lead to antigenic drift (mutations), which can reduce vaccine effectiveness.
